7#ifndef SPECTRA_SYM_EIGS_SOLVER_H
8#define SPECTRA_SYM_EIGS_SOLVER_H
9
10#include <Eigen/Core>
11
12#include "HermEigsBase.h"
13#include "Util/SelectionRule.h"
14#include "MatOp/DenseSymMatProd.h"
15
16namespace Spectra {
17
18///
19/// \ingroup EigenSolver
20///
21/// This class implements the eigen solver for real symmetric matrices, i.e.,
22/// to solve \f$Ax=\lambda x\f$ where \f$A\f$ is symmetric.
23///
24/// **Spectra** is designed to calculate a specified number (\f$k\f$)
25/// of eigenvalues of a large square matrix (\f$A\f$). Usually \f$k\f$ is much
26/// less than the size of the matrix (\f$n\f$), so that only a few eigenvalues
27/// and eigenvectors are computed.
28///
29/// Rather than providing the whole \f$A\f$ matrix, the algorithm only requires
30/// the matrix-vector multiplication operation of \f$A\f$. Therefore, users of
31/// this solver need to supply a class that computes the result of \f$Av\f$
32/// for any given vector \f$v\f$. The name of this class should be given to
33/// the template parameter `OpType`, and instance of this class passed to
34/// the constructor of SymEigsSolver.
35///
36/// If the matrix \f$A\f$ is already stored as a matrix object in **Eigen**,
37/// for example `Eigen::MatrixXd`, then there is an easy way to construct such a
38/// matrix operation class, by using the built-in wrapper class DenseSymMatProd
39/// that wraps an existing matrix object in **Eigen**. This is also the
40/// default template parameter for SymEigsSolver. For sparse matrices, the
41/// wrapper class SparseSymMatProd can be used similarly.
42///
43/// If the users need to define their own matrix-vector multiplication operation
44/// class, it should define a public type `Scalar` to indicate the element type,
45/// and implement all the public member functions as in DenseSymMatProd.
46///
47/// \tparam OpType The name of the matrix operation class. Users could either
48/// use the wrapper classes such as DenseSymMatProd and
49/// SparseSymMatProd, or define their own that implements the type
50/// definition `Scalar` and all the public member functions as in
51/// DenseSymMatProd.
52///
53/// Below is an example that demonstrates the usage of this class.
54///
55/// \code{.cpp}
56/// #include <Eigen/Core>
57/// #include <Spectra/SymEigsSolver.h>
58/// // <Spectra/MatOp/DenseSymMatProd.h> is implicitly included
59/// #include <iostream>
60///
61/// using namespace Spectra;
62///
63/// int main()
64/// {
65/// // We are going to calculate the eigenvalues of M
66/// Eigen::MatrixXd A = Eigen::MatrixXd::Random(10, 10);
67/// Eigen::MatrixXd M = A + A.transpose();
68///
69/// // Construct matrix operation object using the wrapper class DenseSymMatProd
70/// DenseSymMatProd<double> op(M);
71///
72/// // Construct eigen solver object, requesting the largest three eigenvalues
73/// SymEigsSolver<DenseSymMatProd<double>> eigs(op, 3, 6);
74///
75/// // Initialize and compute
76/// eigs.init();
77/// int nconv = eigs.compute(SortRule::LargestAlge);
78///
79/// // Retrieve results
80/// Eigen::VectorXd evalues;
81/// if (eigs.info() == CompInfo::Successful)
82/// evalues = eigs.eigenvalues();
83///
84/// std::cout << "Eigenvalues found:\n" << evalues << std::endl;
85///
86/// return 0;
87/// }
88/// \endcode
89///
90/// And here is an example for user-supplied matrix operation class.
91///
92/// \code{.cpp}
93/// #include <Eigen/Core>
94/// #include <Spectra/SymEigsSolver.h>
95/// #include <iostream>
96///
97/// using namespace Spectra;
98///
99/// // M = diag(1, 2, ..., 10)
100/// class MyDiagonalTen
101/// {
102/// public:
103/// using Scalar = double; // A typedef named "Scalar" is required
104/// int rows() const { return 10; }
105/// int cols() const { return 10; }
106/// // y_out = M * x_in
107/// void perform_op(double *x_in, double *y_out) const
108/// {
109/// for (int i = 0; i < rows(); i++)
110/// {
111/// y_out[i] = x_in[i] * (i + 1);
112/// }
113/// }
114/// };
115///
116/// int main()
117/// {
118/// MyDiagonalTen op;
119/// SymEigsSolver<MyDiagonalTen> eigs(op, 3, 6);
120/// eigs.init();
121/// eigs.compute(SortRule::LargestAlge);
122/// if (eigs.info() == CompInfo::Successful)
123/// {
124/// Eigen::VectorXd evalues = eigs.eigenvalues();
125/// // Will get (10, 9, 8)
126/// std::cout << "Eigenvalues found:\n" << evalues << std::endl;
127/// }
128///
129/// return 0;
130/// }
131/// \endcode
132///
133template <typename OpType = DenseSymMatProd<double>>
134class SymEigsSolver : public HermEigsBase<OpType, IdentityBOp>
135{
136private:
137 using Index = Eigen::Index;
138
139public:
140 ///
141 /// Constructor to create a solver object.
142 ///
143 /// \param op The matrix operation object that implements
144 /// the matrix-vector multiplication operation of \f$A\f$:
145 /// calculating \f$Av\f$ for any vector \f$v\f$. Users could either
146 /// create the object from the wrapper class such as DenseSymMatProd, or
147 /// define their own that implements all the public members
148 /// as in DenseSymMatProd.
149 /// \param nev Number of eigenvalues requested. This should satisfy \f$1\le nev \le n-1\f$,
150 /// where \f$n\f$ is the size of matrix.
151 /// \param ncv Parameter that controls the convergence speed of the algorithm.
152 /// Typically a larger `ncv` means faster convergence, but it may
153 /// also result in greater memory use and more matrix operations
154 /// in each iteration. This parameter must satisfy \f$nev < ncv \le n\f$,
155 /// and is advised to take \f$ncv \ge 2\cdot nev\f$.
156 ///
157 SymEigsSolver(OpType& op, Index nev, Index ncv) :
158 HermEigsBase<OpType, IdentityBOp>(op, IdentityBOp(), nev, ncv)
159 {}
160};
161
162} // namespace Spectra
163
164#endif // SPECTRA_SYM_EIGS_SOLVER_H
165
